												El mejor Sci-Fi RPG que jugué en mi vida... una excelente historia, muy de película, bastante sombría y dramática.El gameplay es más dinámico que el Mass Effect 1, pudiendo hacer una enfrentación sin tener que pausear para que la squad use sus poderes bióticos, o sin tener que pausear para cambiar el tipo de munición.Los gráficos son más oscuros y nítidos en color, eso le da una linda atmósfera, sintiendo estar en otro juego, sacándote la idea de una expansión del 1.¿Si necesitás haber jugado el primero para entender el segundo?Para nada, aunque algunos personajes vuelven, las decisiones que tomaste (las cuales cambia todo, ya que incluso hay decisiones de vida o muerte, tanto de la squad como propias) se mantienen, aunque si no importás el savegame del primero, las decisiones serían las "default".Explorar la Vía Láctea, conocer e interactuar con otras razas, explorar planetas y lunas (incluso nuestra Luna), con una fantástica historia. ME2.

content:
y 12, 2016
												Having just recently replayed Mass Effect 2 I was shocked at just how well everything has held up. People praise ME2 for being one of the greatest games made and it's hard to argue. Mass Effect 2 is a truly remarkable game and what makes it that way isn't any one aspect, but the interplay between all the systems that has allowed it to shine. Only by skillfully weaving the elements of combat, story, art and sound together did the men and women of BioWare create such a remarkable experience. But there's one additional system that has helped elevate Mass Effect 2 to such a timeless classic. The players. By adding our own personal stories to the tapestry already laid out by BioWare did each and everyone of us create their own indelible experiences that will always hold up to the test of time. Mass Effect 2 respects the player's choices and because of that it will ALWAYS be that good.

SummaryHonestly, doing a review for such an already ubiquitous game may well be a pointless exercise, but to be honest I just played this game for 40 hours in 3 days and I wanted a place to put my thoughts. The game isn't perfect, but it's damn good. The few flaws are mostly a consequence of the development being focused towards consoles, but they aren't game destroying.Also I'm writing this withough having read any other reviews - it was a bit of an impulse buy - so apologies if I repeat everything you've already read, or completely miss the point somewhere.Pros:Immersive worldFantastic writingVoice actingShootingCons:Texture quality/general graphics optionsVariety of combatKeybindingsFacial expressions made by ShepardStory (Spoiler free)Frankly, this is the only reason anyone should get this game. If you have no interest in storytelling whatsoever, there are much better shooters out there; if you have no interest in shooters, it's not worth being put off. The story is very immersive, with an incredibly fleshed out world, and more than makes up for any flaws the game has in other areas. Characters don't feel neglected, although sometimes there isn't quite enough content for a character you want to experience more of. (Side note: You may get a mixed first impression of "The Salarian", which could prompt you to stop going out of your way to talk to him. This is the sensible option if you wish to preserve your sides later in the game. Some of his lines are just golden.)If you haven't played Mass Effect 1, I would recommend playing it first, even if it is mechanically slightly inferior to it's sequel, and you can play it without. However, a lot of enjoyment can be derived from taking a single Shepard, with all his actions, choices, and in my case, awful facial hair, through the series.CombatSatisfying, though slightly repetitive. The cover system can be awkward to use at times, thanks to Use, Sprint, and Take Cover all forcibly bound to the same action - by far the ugliest scar from the console port. If, like I did, you want to play with the same controls as every other PC shooter in the universe, the easiest fix is to use the primary and secondary keybinding functionality to bind the do-everything button to both what you want the Use and Sprint buttons to be. Often you'll be sprinting into cover anyway, so it kind of works, but it's definitely not ideal.There's a lot of variety to be had in terms of the ways you can build Shepard, but during a single playthrough it can get fairly restrictive, especially if you want to play optimally. That said, the variety in squadmates can allow a few different tactical approaches for the same Shepard, even if you only get to experience their skills and playstyle via the tactics interface, which carries over nicely from Mass Effect 1.Roleplaying and MoralityThe morality system is extremely black and white, which can be an issue, but if you stick to any non-gamey moral compass for your Shepard, it will probably see you pick up a good few Paragon and Renegade points each. Additionally, some choices don't really fall under stereotypical "good" and "evil" labels either way, but they assign Parargon and Renegade points to them anyway, so it doesn't always make sense. I didn't find it really hindered me in any way though. The feeling of decisions having an impact in the world is always great, though.

												The Stuff of legends... Fans of Starwars Knights of the old republic 1&2, this is the game you've been missing. It may not satisfy the diehard Starwarsaphiles but as far as game mechanics, interactivestorytelling, cause and effect style consequences, and the whole play how you want, who you want, when you want, and where you want in whatever order you want to will keep you immersed and hold your attention for at minimum 3 play thru's. In fact, when you factor in acheivements, multiple (several) romances avenues, Perfect good outcome, Perfect bad outcome, Gaining max loyalty of your teammates, and all the DLC's (which depending on your moral values, are easily obtainable, and free) your unlikely to lose interest prior to a 3rd playthrough. Guides are mostly awesome, and there is a fix availible (easy to apply) to give you full xbox console controller support.  Lots of mods are availible also, but its already a perfect game so don't expect to use them until you've finished your first playthrough. All in all people who played SWKOTR repeatedly will love this game, as far as the "But its not starwars" crowd, its in space, with a spaceship, And multiple planets. ~Use your imagination, pretend alittle.10/10

4, 2015
												don't expect a outstanding shooter/rpg, this game is carried solely by its characters.most of the levels outside of towns are designed like tubes or arenas with the occasional branch which always lead back together at some point, exploring for hidden items is limited. the fighting/shooting is nothing to write home about. the majority of skills you can unlock aren't to exciting either.biggest con are probEably the mini games most of them are fun for the first few times BUT they are HOPELESSLY overused, especialy mining/probing for minerals becomes a very annoying chore after the first couple of planets, expect to spend atleast half of your total game time just harvesting planets if you are the hoarding type of player.once you reach the end of the game you realise you only needed a small fraction of all the minerals that you can mine to unlock all upgrades, perfect example for a artifical game-time extender.the main story is ok but the thing that kept me playing till the end are the dialogues, facial expressions and overall very good design of every character, creature and even most of the enviorments and their individual storys that make this game-univers so believable and intersting.

content:
er 26, 2015
												This is a fantastic game. The gameplay is fun, and has a clean layout bar for all your biotics. There is alot of fun to be had. The story took me around 25 hours to complete, and it was epic from start to finish. The pacing of it is also really good. The share of time with the story and gameplay are near perfect, and Bioware definetly knew their strong points in the developement. The RPG factor of this game is also really well made, with dialogue options that progress into relationships and story, and an interesting karma system similar to SWTOR and Fallout: New Vegas that unlock more dialogue options. The graphics are pretty good too, but I'm not gonna go into detail about that since this is a 5 year old game. The sound design helps set the theme for a futuristic galaxy very well, and there are a few songs from the official soundtrack that I really like. Now... technical issues. The game crashed on me twice. I don't know why, but they did. Also one time, I was floating in the air walking around, which was hilarious until I found out couldn't get down. Luckily I could just load the previous autosave. Seriously though, this is still a fantastic game. There's a HUGE galaxy to explore, and a ton of planets to visit or even mine resources from. Even when you finish the storyline and feel those chills from that EPIC ending mission, you can still continue travelling around the Milky Way completing sidequests. Not only is Mass Effect 2 a fantastic game, but it is now one of the best games I have ever played.

content:
er 30, 2014
												Played 20+ hours of this in a single weekend, I literally could not put it down. The possibility of creating your own character and dictate it's decisions and personality provides for one of the most immersive gaming experiences you'll ever have. This is what games should always be, an interactive media where, instead of just inputting action, you're writing your own path and telling your own story, molding the framework the developers created into your liking. This is what a true interactive media should be like.Mass Effect 2 is a masterpiece, filled with the most interesting characters and settings I've ever seen in a video game, stellar gameplay, amazing storytelling and music and the most rewarding - and thrilling - choice mechanic. I cannot praise it enough. A true masterpiece that shows what video games are capable of as a true artform, building upon cinematic language and adding interactivity and the instrument of choice to become the ultimate storytelling medium.To sum it up, don't waste an opportunity to experience Mass Effect 2 at least once in your life. (P.S.: I recommend this specially to Star Trek fans, trust me on that one)

content:
y 8, 2014
												The first thing you notice about this sequel to Space Marine Inventory Manager 2007 is the complete lack of having to manage your space marine's inventory, which oddly enough improves the game no end!You've played the first Mass Effect, right? If so, you know the drill. ME2 delivers more of the good stuff, refines or removes the not-so-good stuff, gives you prettier visuals, etc. BioWare/EA once again test the patience of PC gamers around the world by not bothering to implement gamepad support and offering a DLC purchasing system so terrible that you'll think twice about throwing money their way.But, despite all of that, ME2 remains one of the most impressive action RPGs of the past decade, delivering an interesting gallery of characters, a better-than-average script and art design that puts many blockbuster sci-fi movies to shame.

content:
2, 2014
												Just finished my second playthrough of 1 thru 3, with a couple of the DLCs installed and the extended cut ending. Believe the positive reviews; this game will stay with you! This is the only experience since the original Deus Ex that has had me invested this way. The three instalments each play slightly differently, but all are worth every penny, especially now! IMHO all three are required, in the right order, for the full story to be appreciated, and to witness the character relationships in their maturity.Incredibly well written, countless inter-related stories and subplots, NPCs that really do come to life through the script, top notch voice acting, and how you choose to interact with them (or not!). Excellent character graphics and animation, numerous interactive cut-scenes, action, exploration, intimacy...I can't recommend this highly enough! The only real problem with the Mass Effect series is what to play afterwards without it feeling bland by comparison!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
y 17, 2014
												Wow.It's hard to overstate how much I enjoyed this game. It is masterful on every level - story, writing, scope, decision making, combat, environmental design, artwork, lighting effects, cinematography, musical score, sound design, and virtually any other area I can think of. It is, without exaggeration, that good.(mini spoiler) And the last mission - any team member you have come to know in the game can die a very permanent death based on your decisions, giving the finale a weight and consequence rarely experienced in video games. (end mini spoiler)What is perhaps most staggering is that even after a 50-hour playthrough (DLC included), you can be sure that you have seen far less than even half of the possibilities that the game has to offer. The original game isn't nearly as perfect, but still worth a run-through for the storyline and decisions that will carry over into the sequel.No, the game is not without faults. For one thing, it's overly easy and overly simplified compared to the original.It doesn't have the same level of cinematic polish that we've come to expect from AAA titles in 2013 and beyond.It gets excessively talkative and stale in certain areas.Much like the previous game, the romance subplots are stupid. If you want your Commander Shepard to get some quick and casual sex, it's not gonna happen. It's deep love or nothing. And that deep love comes out of nowhere, since your intimate conversations with any given love interest are extremely limited.But by far the worst of Mass Effect 2's problems is the very time-consuming process of grinding for resources, which isn't any fun at all. There are nearly endless amounts of resources available, but the game doesn't tell you how many you need. While there are ship upgrades available later in the game to make these processes quicker, the game doesn't tell you about them, and so you may waste much time in the first half grinding before acquiring them. My advice: grind at a minimum until you get the upgrades, and then only focus on "rich" planets, since there are more than enough to get you through.(Issues)I want to mention a few minor issues that you might run into. I frequently clipped through objects and got stuck, forcing a reload, and there are a few missions tied to DLC that resulted in game-breaking crashes. The latter problem was easily rectified by creating a shortcut to the .exe and putting -nomoviestartup in the parameters. One last very strange glitch resulted in my player character stretching her arms out to the sides, unable to shoot or interact anymore, solved only by reloading an earlier save and trying different dialogue choices before the bug. With a game this big, my recommendation is to keep numerous save files and save often.Overall, Mass Effect 2 is definitely one of my favorite games of 2010, matched only by Red Dead Redemption. In my book, that's saying a lot.9/10

ber 17, 2016
												You won't know the true meaning of cinematic story telling unless you have played this game. The setting, the art style, voice acting and the pace is just: https://i.redd.it/vmaai3h6j8ix.pngThere is an interactive galaxy map where you can fly your ship from planet to planet, or use mass relays and teleport from one point of the galaxy to another. Each planet that you land feels so different and alive. Gameplay is fun, fresh and exciting. They give you 6 classes to choose from that suits all type of gameplay.I was so obsessed with preparing for the sucide mission that I had forgot to romance with anyone in this game. So no comment there.A recap on Mass Effect 1: 


YouTube™ Video: Mass Effect Synopsis/Summary (HD) 

			Views: 18,686		

			This is the Mass Effect "Story so far.." from Bioware's Website. It's a quick Mass Effect digest video summarizing what happened leading up to Mass Effect 2.		

Sypnosis of Mass Effect 2: The game starts off with the Normandy being attacked by an unknown ship and Shepard being killed in action. He was later on brought back by Ceberus, lead by the Illusive Man, who assigned him on a mission to investigate why the humans colonies have been disappearing. After discovering that it was the Collectors who are behind these abductions, the same species that are responsible for the destruction of Normandy and Shepard's death, the commander must scout the galaxy and build the best team to take the fight to the Collectors.

content:
12, 2016
   My Playthrough   Youtube Playlist    The Review Mass Effect 2 is an interesting case. While this game does add a lot of things like more exploitable cities, more companions, and a much bigger ship. They also removed some content as well like exploring uncharted worlds with the M35 Mako, the 60 level cap, a lot of talents, and worse of all the ability to talk to your companions at any time. 
This game does have some pros like the story is still good and the companions are well written and voice acted. The gamEplay is still the same as the prequel but now their is ammo and weapon restrictions. The cons are mostly all the things that Bioware removed from Mass Effect but a big one is that this game is far more linear than ME1. Now you can recruit any companions that you want and you have to wait for specific points to recruit your favorite companions. From all the negitives that I listed you are probably wondering why I am still recommending this game. Well while this game is not as great as Mass Effect it is still a good game and I recommend playing it.

content:
er 26, 2016
												The sequel to the game that launched a universe and an epic franchise. Mass Effect 2 expands upon its origins with tighter gameplay and smooth visuals. A stripped down version in some respects compared to the first game, but not to its detriment. Gone are a lot of the more fiddly micromanagement RPG elements of sorting out gear for your teammates, as well as the long driving sections. The only tedious aspect of the game are the scanning elements of planets, but even things like this are sometimes helpful in drawing you into the universe growing before your eyes. Now if only EA would be Mass Effect 3 on Steam...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												Okay, this is the best game i have ever played in my life. It has such an awesome story and characters. All of the things you do, all the thing you say matter. Its not just some random game you can play and don`t care about anything, you get attached to your crew and story by itself feels deep and inspiring. The Music in Mass Effect is utterly awe inspiring. It's music that any true Mass Effect fan has felt empowered by, saddened by, inspired by, and moved by. Even on it's own, out of context of the three absolutely stunning games, it always provokes emotion from me. Mass Effect is the greatest RPG series of all time, and it's OST more than lives up to the story and experience. When it came to the end, when everything came down to the wire, everything that you did in the game came out. You put everything on the line, everything you had, and through sheer willpower, and sacrifice, and tremendous effort, YOU did it. Your team. You. You saw in detail how every choice you made in the game came into play in that final half hour of the game. If you failed, it wasn't some planet you'd never seen, or countless random soldiers you didn't care about, it was your teammates that you'd fought with for hours and hours of gametime, characters you'd built relationships with and honestly come to see as friends. The Suicide Mission is one of the best end-levels in history. The fact that you choose your teammates for each task and aren't told which one is clearly the best made it feel so immersive. You actually had to know them, not just take them for missions as if they are dumb robots. The Mass Effect Trilogy (Mass Effect 2 in particular) is not just one of the great video games ever created, but it's also one of the greatest works of Sci-Fi ever.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 13, 2015
												Mass Effect 2 is a great sequel to an equally impressive game. While I do believe that this second installment is a bit over-praised, it is still an incredible game that builds on the successes of its predecessor very well.I do believe that most components of the combat system are improved. The only small detail that I don't personally enjoy is a matter of personal preference and doesn't really bother me, as it is present in most shooters anyways. The visuals are obviously much more impressive as well and make an impact on immersion in this case. Overall, the gameplay mechanics have been vastly improved as far as fluidity and functionality.What truly matters when evaluating this title, however, is the narrative and the ability of the game to make you care about its characters and its stories. While I personally believe that the first Mass Effect did a better job of making the player care about each and every character and his or her story, Mass Effect 2 still retains the important features that characterize the NPCs and make the story memorable and cannot be criticized for a lack of story; my personal opinion shouldn't have an impact on the validity and inspiration of the title. The fundamental RPG elements of Mass Effect 2 make it stand above virtually any other RPG on the market today.Mass Effect 2 is an amazing game and is undoubtedly a must-own title.

er 26, 2016
												Contrary to what some may say, this is the most polished and enjoyable (and probably underestimated) part of the trilogy. The atmosphere and the flow are just great, scenery is fantastic, dialogs aren't boring or idiotic, the combat mechanics work just fine, and the characters are most memorable, unlike the first part where there were not developed as they could have been, or the third part with its combined Jersey Shore / SJW paradox. The missions unfold like episodes of a great TV show continuing on a successful movie. Couldn't recommend it more, especially if playing with all the DLC-s (unfortunately, in that case you should probably get the Origin version like I did).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 12
												Yet another EPIC game from bioware, and the second installment of the Mass Effect Series, just as epic, if not moreso, as the first. Choices still matter,and you see some of your choices from the first game making big and little waves in your story; actions matter, who lives, who dies, who do you save....I only have 33.4 hours on steam with this game, but over 100 on Origin (more DLC available on origin). This game along with the first are beyond amazing, this second installment is much darker than the first game.  The Reapers are back, only this time they're using the mysterious Collectors instead of the Geth, whole human colonies are vanishing without a trace, no signs left behind, no struggle, nothing.  Its up to you, to find out why/how and put a stop to it.You have new companions, with returning faces, and a whole other side of the universe to explore and tame.I recommend this game whole heartedly, the graphics hold up to the test of time, the decisions still matter, and it still hits you right in the feels, and keeps on delivering with an epic stoy.

content:
er 28, 2015
												THIS IS THE BEST SCI-FI ACTION RPG IN EXISTANCE!!!!That is NOT opinion, it is downright fact, you WILL NOT find a better game in the entire genre.If you can get past the dated gameplay / graphics of the first game, you will be enthralled in the story, some of the most beloved characters in gaming.90% of every decision you make in the game, especially who you decide to kill or let live, can have SERIOUS impacts on not just the first game, but the OTHER two games as well, such as who you bring with you on your team for all 3 games, how you approach combat and dialogue, even what missions you get to do!you MUST play all 3 games in order, you CANNOT play them in a random order, you will severely hinder your experience, and believe me, the first experience with mass effect only comes along once, if you mix up the games (e.g starting from the third game, then the first, then the second)  you will have ruined one of the best gaming experiences you can potentially have.You can only purchase the first two games on Steam, but it gets put on sale, you MUST buy the Mass Effect Collection Edition, it provides you with the first game, and the digital deluxe edition of the second game in one cheap bundle, and the third game can only be purchased on origin, in total, youll be paying £18-40 (depending on if you purchase during sales)  for 3 games that will easily take up 20 hours each to complete.not to mention, Mass Effect 3 has a multiplayer, and it is STILL one of the most enjoyable co-op horde games to date.if you love games....just...if you love games, then you have to play this epic trilogy.

content:
31, 2013
												How do you describe a game that is so extraordinary as Mass Effect 2? Where do you begin? With the superb graphics, that stand with the best today? Do you go with the gameplay that feels a thousand times more polished than the first with absolutely tons of available sidequests as well as Downloadable content? Maybe with the fact that this is the first story game that has allowed a player to carry over player-made decisions onto another game, and with this comes a promise that the character you crafted to YOUR expectations would be waiting for you in this story. (That alone is something that gamers like myself have been waiting years for.) And don't even get me started on the story and where the team at Bioware is taking this series. Not only are your character relationships you made in ME1 still intact, but now they have new and truly exciting avenues that they can take. This is doubly true for the Lair of The Shadow Broker DLC with character Liara T'soni. (Highly recommended, along with all the other DLC) Then there is Shephard. The hero who has a bit more personality than before, is forged through player decisions that can alter the state of your party dramatically. And forging him or her is another matter altogether. How exactly do you craft a character who is the most important human in the galaxy? And more, a character who knows it? These elements are sheer brilliance and the amazing experience gifted to us in the first is grossly intensified. The action feels real and livid. The romantic stories feel romantic (particularly with Garrus, Thane, Jack and Tali Zorah, who seem the slightly less than obvious choices) And the music (yes, I'm yet again, going into the music) composed by Jack Wall fits the situations of the game even better than the first entry. Some take issue with the mining and doorlock minigames because of their repetitive nature. To me, it is small potatoes considering the rest of the experience. By the end, you feel the weight of your decisions and their consequences on your shoulders, be they good or bad. The brilliant thing, though, is that you've felt this all along.10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 15, 2015
												I used to think Mass Effect 1 was the best in the series, and used to be very biased toward it. After recently playing through Mass Effect 2 though, I have to say that I think this one is the best in the series. While I do miss a lot of the RPG aspects that Mass Effect 1 offered, and were removed from Mass Effect 2, I think the overall improvements to Mass Effect 2 overshadow that. The TPS aspects are way more solid, and feel a lot tighter. They also added an ammo system to the game and removed the heat aspect. While I did enjoy the heat aspect of Mass Effect 1, and figuring out ways to manage it, the ammo system works out in the end. I may also be one of the only ones that actually enjoyed using the Mako, but even though it was replaced in this game with a scan type of thing on planets, it makes it a lot more streamlined. Overall, the story and storytelling is awesome in Mass Effect 2. Everything in Mass Effect 2 is more streamlined, and feels a lot more solid compared to Mass Effect 1. It's a great game, and I definitely recommend it to fans of Mass Effect 1, or just fans of deep storylines, and Shooter/RPG fans.

r 26, 2013
												A truly great sequel which is on par, if not better than the first game. Where the first game had the best story(imo), this sequel greatly expanded upon the gameplay elements. But dont let that fool you. Mass Effect 2 still delivers an epic story where as old faces return while new ones are introduced. Where the first game was clearly a rpg, this sequel has been labeled as an actionrpg, to reach out to a broader audience. Many would say that this is a bad thing, but the game is more fluid as well as some of the rpg elements have been toned down. That isn't necessarily a bad thing as this was often quite grueling in Mass Effect 1. So overall it expands on its predecessor when it comes to gameplay, lore and characters. Even though the story in Mass Effect 1 was better(again imo), this sequel still got an epic storyline as it is a continuation of the first game.

content:
3, 2015
My personal review for Mass Effect 2.This review has been made with the intent of having as little spoilers as possible, but it's inevitable. Read with caution.Short Plot Synopsis: Mass Effect 2 takes place weeks after the first game, starting with Commander Shepard (Mark Meer or Jennifer Hale) and the crew of the Normandy searching through a sector where three ships have gone missing within one month. After spending four days finding nothing, the Normandy is attacked by an unknown ship, ripping it apart. The crew evacuates, and Commander Shepard tosses Jeff "Joker" Moreau (Seth Green), the ship's pilot, into the last available Evacuation Pod. Shepard is thrown aside from the pod to a control panel, where he closes off the Evac Pod and sends Joker to safety. However, an explosion damages Shepard's suit, causing a breach, leaving Shepard to ultimately asphyxiate and fall into the nearby planet. Shortly after death, a company named Cerberus, that has a bad reputation for extremist behaviours to secure the fate of Humanity, recovers Shepard's body from the surface of the planet. Cerberus then creates and begins the "Lazarus Project", the act to revive Shepard. The process takes two years, and Shepard's awakening wasn't pleasant. When he finally awakens, alarm bells are going off in the Research Station. The ship's own Security Mechs have turned rogue, and the ship needs to be evacuated. This begins Mass Effect 2.Features:           - Re-take the role of Commander Shepard, defeater of Saren and saviour of the Citadel, and control him through the events of Mass Effect 2.           - Carry off from where you left off; Choices from Mass Effect 1 affect Mass Effect 2. You can also import your previous character. You are also able to import your Mass Effect 2 character into Mass Effect 3, where your decisions will affect the story and your crew. Though it involves a little bit of work, details later on.           - Every choice matters; Whether it's delaying a mission, or helping out your crew, every decision will influence your outcome and determine your crew's fate.           - Personalization; You can shape Shepard into your own view of them, making Shepard either Male or Female, and having control over their looks, personality, armour style, class, abilities, and weapons.           - Moral System; The Mass Effect series has a moral compass with two sides; Paragon and Renegade. However, unlike numerous other moral compases that determines being either one or the other, Mass Effect brings a new idea to the table. It tracks both your Paragon and Renegade sides at the same time, meaning if you choose to spare someone, but extort someone for a discount, sparing that person will not balance out your moral compass. Unlike Mass Effect, there is no more Charm or Intimidate skill. They are now determined solely by your Paragon and Renegade standings, respectfully. Having enough Moral Standing points, you can then use special dialogue options, as well as a new feature introduced in Mass Effect 2 called "Interrupts". These are special dialogue options used when other characters are talking, activated with the mouse buttons. Using these can cause impacts on the story, such as calming down two characters before they end up fighting, point out other characters immoral choices, or even assault a character entirely. Another interesting feature is your moral standing affects Shepard's appearance. If you choose a Paragon path, Shepard's scars from the Lazarus Project will heal and start to disappear. However, if you choose Renegade, those scars will deepen and show more.           - A wide crew, made of different races. Your personal squad, who will assist in battle, is interchangable, and comes with the ability with choosing their loadout and abilities. If you do your squadmate's loyalty missions, they will gain a unique ability, and this will help with the end-game.           - The ability to use your teammates abilities when you want to.           - Unique, original plot, with lots of mechanics you can't find elsewhere.           - The universe is vast, full of interesting species and races, each with their own quirks and personalities.           - You are able to create relationships with your crew members, that will affect the story in the next game.           - Has a Planet-Scanning mini-game, where you search for different minerals and possibly side-missions on different planets.           - New hacking minigames, including connecting Matching Pins and selecting matching pieces of code.           - New Game+ Mode.           - And many more features.Pros           + Many customizable character and armour features. You are able to shape Shepard into your own image of him/her, choose your own class with their own set of abilities, choose your backstory, personalize your armour with different material and patterns, and mix-and-match armour pieces. Each piece of armour also has different effects, meaning one helmet could grant extra health, while another could improve accuracy.           + Deep story, with a fair amount of lore. The developers specifically noted to make the side-quests as deep as the main story.           + Every choice matters, each with their own consequences. Will characters agree with your actions, or frown upon them?           + Many new characters, each with their own detailed backstory.           + Brings back old characters from Mass Effect 1, with their own story of what they've been up to since Shepard had died.           + The ability to import your Mass Effect 1 character into Mass Effect 2, with all the decisions you have made in the first game affecting the story in the second one.           + The ability to import your Mass Effect 2 character into Mass Effect 3, though this comes with a little bit of work. Again, I'll explain further in.           + The outcome will be entirely determined on the player's decisions.           + Able to interact with and get to know your crew. You will be able to do specific missions for them, to gain their loyalty, unlocking a specific ability for them.           + Like I said in the features, Mass Effect has a very unique plot and story, with mechanics found hardly anywhere else.           + Nice graphics, even for a 5 year old game. It even runs smoothly for the amount of effects it has.           + The Mass Effect series has had a Heavy influence on lots of sci-fi games.Neutral           +- You won't find yourself short on Credits anytime soon. Every mission is funded by Cerberus, and will include at least a 20,000 credit payroll at the end of the mission. You can also find additional credits on PDA's, Terminals, Wall Safe's, and (for some reason), Medi-kits. However, Purchases are evened out to higher prices to even this out.           +- "I'm Commander Shepard, and this is my favourite store on the Citadel." You can endorse numerous stores on the Citadel with this line, which could technically create conflicts. It has no effect on the game though. However, this isn't a good way of laying low if you choose to tell the security guards at the entrance you would prefer the records to state that Shepard has died. Again, endorsing numerous stores has no effect on that choice.           +- It requires a little bit of work to transfer your ME2 save file to ME3, due to ME3 only being available to Origin.Cons           - The game has DLC, but it's not available on Steam.           - If Shepard dies in the end-game, you can not import your save to ME3.           - Mini-games can get repetitive.Final DecisionI highly recommend this game. Mass Effect had a large impact on the Sci-Fi genre, and for good reason. I'll admit I had to cut a few points due to character limit, but I covered most of it. This is a fantastic game series, 8.9/10.

												I cant think of another example of how gaming could be done right, better than the Mass Effect series.An epic trilogy that spans three games in which you are in control of how the story evolves around you.Mass Effect 2 lived up to everything that was expected of this great space epic and is an amzing sequel to the its predecessor.Pros:-Ability to import ME 1 character and profile-Very good animation and graphics, voice acting is great-Great Combat with new powers and weapons-Streamlined Upgrades and Weapons-Your choices shape the story (especially the ones from the first game)-Even more characters, with interesting backstories-Side quest are more tied in and diverse-Very engaging story-REPLAYABILITYCons:-Planet Scanning for upgradesBioware did a great job taking Mass Effect to the next level and clearly deserves better than being owned by EA, but the Mass Effect series is sill the best example of how passionate game making is done right.

content:
2014
												Mass Effect 2 had a lot to live up to, and wow did it fail. At first.The base game for Mass Effect 2 was devoid of almost everything that made the original great. Each mission was nothing more than killing some guys with no option to do anything else. Inventory management was completely removed from the game and the gameplay became that of a shooter - choose mission, go to instance, kill guys, cutscene. But, - and this is a big but - the DLC does a lot to fix this game. Where the base game was devoid of anything but the main mission, the DLC adds much-needed hand-crafted content - and just enough for me to recommend this game (with DLC).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 29, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 adds another chapter in the Mass Effect trilogy, and it does so pretty damn well. It's been argued this game has the best plot out of the three games, and I'd say that's a fair statement. They really liven it up compared to the first Mass Effect. That being said, you'd be doing yourself a great disservice if you didn't play the first game before this one; you won't understand what ANYONE is saying. More importantly, you'll be missing out on crafting your very own story, making those important decisions in ME1, and that's what really stands out about this series. The gameplay is more refined, and smoother than the first, but dumbed down. A lot of the RPG'ness is sucked out of this one, which some people like. You can't customize your weapons or armor as extensively as you could like in one, but it isn't a complete loss; the game is still utterly fantastic and worth your time. All in all, this is an important step in the story of Commander Shepard, and until you beat it, you'll be absorbed.

content:
, 2011
												A great sequel to an excellent sci-fi game.  I personally recomend playing the first one as that is still a great game unless you are more a shooter fan than an RPG fan in which case I woudl start here.  The combat is perhaps the biggest improvement and brings the game up to par with lots of other action games.  The characters and side quests were also improved over the original.  The main downsides are the story which very much has that "middle chapter" feel but is still good and the rpg feel which was dialed back too much for my tastes and may turn off other rpg fans.  But especially at today's prices this would easily be one of the first games I would point you to if you were looking for a great sci-fi game to play.

content:
ber 4, 2013
												While Mass Effect (1) was a good story, had some good elements, the game was simply one of the worst, mechanically speaking, games I've played in a long time, yes I understand I'm late to the party, and that its and old and was an experimental game, but the mechanics itself put me so much off the series when I played it at release, and still do when I now try to play it again, its simply a waste of time and not to my liking. Simply watch a video or read the lore to get the story of it, and jump to Mass Effect 2 right away!Mass Effect 2 is in every single way better. It's smoother, game-play feels a lot better, the game mechanics are pretty damn solid now and the story, is a blast.The game is very good at making you feel in control of the crew, the ship and last but not least, control of your character. You feel bound to the people around you, you feel their pain, happiness and suffering.While you progress the "main" story arc, you will get multiple "side-missions" that will not only give you rewards and experience, but also in some ways, make you feel more connected to the planets and galaxies, giving you a higher incentive of beating anything in your path, anything for humanity and the safety of the galaxy, you clearly show, no matter who's in charge, you will get the job done.And with the help of people you meet along the way, recruit, talk to, consider your closest allies, you can take down even greater threats.Along the story arc line, your companions will ask you for help, doing so will make them more "Loyal" towards you and what you stand for, but it's not all a cakewalk, you get to see some dark sides of certain characters that change the view of them completely, they can put you in hard spots, do you do as they want? Do you keep them from doing something stupid? What is right? And, what is wrong?In the end it's all up to you to decide, and it will reflect on you, and your ship crew.So the question then is, should you play this or not? Is it worth the price? Hellyeah it is, the game can get picked up for cheap and nothing now, Mass Effect 2 is a huge improvement over its predecessor, not only in the way the game looks, but the game mechanics in general are a lot more smooth, feel good to use and best of all, no more irritating screens that pop up and take hours away.

content:
y 29, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 adds another chapter in the Mass Effect trilogy, and it does so pretty damn well. It's been argued this game has the best plot out of the three games, and I'd say that's a fair statement. They really liven it up compared to the first Mass Effect. That being said, you'd be doing yourself a great disservice if you didn't play the first game before this one; you won't understand what ANYONE is saying. More importantly, you'll be missing out on crafting your very own story, making those important decisions in ME1, and that's what really stands out about this series. The gameplay is more refined, and smoother than the first, but dumbed down. A lot of the RPG'ness is sucked out of this one, which some people like. You can't customize your weapons or armor as extensively as you could like in one, but it isn't a complete loss; the game is still utterly fantastic and worth your time. All in all, this is an important step in the story of Commander Shepard, and until you beat it, you'll be absorbed.

												The sequel to the previous game (as sequels tend to be) in the series, Mass Effect 2 fixes the inventory system and rids itself of the Mako (which had horrible controls for anyone who remembers) and drastically increases it's storyline, adding in new characters and building on top of the choices you made in the previous game.This is widely regarded as the best game in the series and with good reason. They're enjoyable, fun to be around, have flaws, and so on and so forth.Just like I advised with the first game, I would suggest having two save games, one where you screw everything up because it's your first time playing, and another where you do some digging and figure out the best way to play the game so everyone makes it home in one piece.And I meant that about the one piece bit. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 9, 2012
												The second, and in my opinion, the best game in the Mass Effect trilogy. Improving upon the first game in every way, but NOT dumbing down many gameplay elements, it introduces a new, dramatic, exciting story full of unpredictable twists and turns, making it look like a spectacular, highly interactive space opera movie.The driving sections around barren planets from ME1 are gone (and replaced with planet scanning, and new driving sections if you own the appropriate DLC), even trivial sidequests have great direction, and seem important even though they do not tie in directly to the main story line. I loved the introduction of clearly Lovecraftian horror elements in the story, something that the third game completely ignored. The Reapers, ancient enemies of all sentient life, are basically intergalactic gods, dangerous even when destroyed, their huge spaceship-like bodies able to brainwash would-be explorers millenia after their "death". It feels you're fighting truly unknown and horrifying adversaries, which gives the game a very unique atmosphere.The characters are unique and believable, dialogue is well-written and interesting, and it's hard to leave the game once you've started playing.Playing ME1 is pretty much a requirement prior to playing ME2, though- after all, it is a continuation of a great storyline.The end is well-rounded, and even though it implies a sequel, it doesn't leave you hanging from a cliff, so to say :)Recommended!P.S. Getting the DLC for this game is a relatively hard process nowadays, thanks to EA's greedy, unoptimized and ham-handed decisions. Basically, you'll have to activate your ME2 copy on Origin, buy DLC on Origin, download them through Bioware Social website, and install them manually after installing (and running) ME2. Why would you do all that?Some DLCs (such as the Arrival and Lair of the Shadow Broker) have story-critical content, along with additional quality gameplay, which adds a lot of new content to the game. If you turn out to be a real fan of the game and hooked on the story of Commander Shepard, you WILL need to play through these additional stories, as they cover some moments heavily referenced in the sequel, Mass Effect 3.EA's way of selling DLC means they NEVER go on a sale, so be prepared to dish out some serious cash for them (individual DLC prices can be several times higher than the price of the base game!!!) and only purchase them if you're REALLY interested in the story. Also, you can safely ignore the "equipment" DLC, as they are really only a money grab, selling you variations of weapons or cosmetic "upgrades" to your team for real money.

ry 28, 2014
												I have not finished playing Mass Effect 2, however I applaud it and its predecessor for its creative use of modern physics to penetrate, if only slightly, the vast distances that lie between stars. Mass Effect 2 also adds more realistic flight sequences, as one has to calculate how much fuel will get them to their destination, acknowledging that fuel is, in fact, a finite resource. However, it does to some extent ignore Newton's first law in that one slows to a halt the minute the ship ceases to accelerate, however, there are worse gripes to be had about a video game than "It follows Aristotelian physics," as Aristotle essentially laid the groundwork for all modern thought.One of my favorite things to do as Commander Shepard was to probe undiscovered worlds, as this was something that I did in real life with the Voyager Probes. However, I doubt that these probes contained anything like the Golden Record that we put together, as First Contact has already been established in the Mass Effect universe.

er 20, 2014
												I give this game a recommendation *ONLY* for the diverse sci-fi tapestry that forms the background to a shallow storyline.  It is obvious the time and energy that went into the computer entrie surrounding the alien races, their homeworlds their history and even their prejudices FAR outweighed the time and energy spent on other things. Not to mention the energy spent on making the communities you encounter seem vibrant and alive.  That being said there is ALOT of regurgitation from KOTOR especially the second.  When I first watched the Ebon Hawk... errr I mean the "Normandy" land on Omega my jaw dropped (the whole scene, it seemed to me, was ripped from KOTOR 2).  Till I realized that ME2 was made by Bioware. Still if video game developers were more like writers half of the cutscenes and characters would come with a disclaimer in the corner *Reproduced From An Earlier Work*.  These things mostly lead to loud guffaws from me as I watched something that seemed so unnervingly similar to somthing I had seen before...... felt like I was playing a KOTOR 3 that lost the rights to use the Star Wars I.P. The other thing about Mass Effect is the constant similarity to Star Trek.  The whole thing with Shepard falling onto a planet, project Lazarus (sounding like a nod to Project Genesis from "The Search for Spock") even the Geth being ideologically near identical to the BORG.  Two major negatives are the semi-dependance on ownership of the first Mass Effect to get crew members and certain side quests (nothing major really just unfortunate to me) and the fact that I found this in the RPG genre when really it's not.  Good for a nice sci-fi vacation but don't expect it to break much from the KOTOR mold that it was obviously pressed from.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
3, 2015
My personal review for Mass Effect 2.This review has been made with the intent of having as little spoilers as possible, but it's inevitable. Read with caution.Short Plot Synopsis: Mass Effect 2 takes place weeks after the first game, starting with Commander Shepard (Mark Meer or Jennifer Hale) and the crew of the Normandy searching through a sector where three ships have gone missing within one month. After spending four days finding nothing, the Normandy is attacked by an unknown ship, ripping it apart. The crew evacuates, and Commander Shepard tosses Jeff "Joker" Moreau (Seth Green), the ship's pilot, into the last available Evacuation Pod. Shepard is thrown aside from the pod to a control panel, where he closes off the Evac Pod and sends Joker to safety. However, an explosion damages Shepard's suit, causing a breach, leaving Shepard to ultimately asphyxiate and fall into the nearby planet. Shortly after death, a company named Cerberus, that has a bad reputation for extremist behaviours to secure the fate of Humanity, recovers Shepard's body from the surface of the planet. Cerberus then creates and begins the "Lazarus Project", the act to revive Shepard. The process takes two years, and Shepard's awakening wasn't pleasant. When he finally awakens, alarm bells are going off in the Research Station. The ship's own Security Mechs have turned rogue, and the ship needs to be evacuated. This begins Mass Effect 2.Features:           - Re-take the role of Commander Shepard, defeater of Saren and saviour of the Citadel, and control him through the events of Mass Effect 2.           - Carry off from where you left off; Choices from Mass Effect 1 affect Mass Effect 2. You can also import your previous character. You are also able to import your Mass Effect 2 character into Mass Effect 3, where your decisions will affect the story and your crew. Though it involves a little bit of work, details later on.           - Every choice matters; Whether it's delaying a mission, or helping out your crew, every decision will influence your outcome and determine your crew's fate.           - Personalization; You can shape Shepard into your own view of them, making Shepard either Male or Female, and having control over their looks, personality, armour style, class, abilities, and weapons.           - Moral System; The Mass Effect series has a moral compass with two sides; Paragon and Renegade. However, unlike numerous other moral compases that determines being either one or the other, Mass Effect brings a new idea to the table. It tracks both your Paragon and Renegade sides at the same time, meaning if you choose to spare someone, but extort someone for a discount, sparing that person will not balance out your moral compass. Unlike Mass Effect, there is no more Charm or Intimidate skill. They are now determined solely by your Paragon and Renegade standings, respectfully. Having enough Moral Standing points, you can then use special dialogue options, as well as a new feature introduced in Mass Effect 2 called "Interrupts". These are special dialogue options used when other characters are talking, activated with the mouse buttons. Using these can cause impacts on the story, such as calming down two characters before they end up fighting, point out other characters immoral choices, or even assault a character entirely. Another interesting feature is your moral standing affects Shepard's appearance. If you choose a Paragon path, Shepard's scars from the Lazarus Project will heal and start to disappear. However, if you choose Renegade, those scars will deepen and show more.           - A wide crew, made of different races. Your personal squad, who will assist in battle, is interchangable, and comes with the ability with choosing their loadout and abilities. If you do your squadmate's loyalty missions, they will gain a unique ability, and this will help with the end-game.           - The ability to use your teammates abilities when you want to.           - Unique, original plot, with lots of mechanics you can't find elsewhere.           - The universe is vast, full of interesting species and races, each with their own quirks and personalities.           - You are able to create relationships with your crew members, that will affect the story in the next game.           - Has a Planet-Scanning mini-game, where you search for different minerals and possibly side-missions on different planets.           - New hacking minigames, including connecting Matching Pins and selecting matching pieces of code.           - New Game+ Mode.           - And many more features.Pros           + Many customizable character and armour features. You are able to shape Shepard into your own image of him/her, choose your own class with their own set of abilities, choose your backstory, personalize your armour with different material and patterns, and mix-and-match armour pieces. Each piece of armour also has different effects, meaning one helmet could grant extra health, while another could improve accuracy.           + Deep story, with a fair amount of lore. The developers specifically noted to make the side-quests as deep as the main story.           + Every choice matters, each with their own consequences. Will characters agree with your actions, or frown upon them?           + Many new characters, each with their own detailed backstory.           + Brings back old characters from Mass Effect 1, with their own story of what they've been up to since Shepard had died.           + The ability to import your Mass Effect 1 character into Mass Effect 2, with all the decisions you have made in the first game affecting the story in the second one.           + The ability to import your Mass Effect 2 character into Mass Effect 3, though this comes with a little bit of work. Again, I'll explain further in.           + The outcome will be entirely determined on the player's decisions.           + Able to interact with and get to know your crew. You will be able to do specific missions for them, to gain their loyalty, unlocking a specific ability for them.           + Like I said in the features, Mass Effect has a very unique plot and story, with mechanics found hardly anywhere else.           + Nice graphics, even for a 5 year old game. It even runs smoothly for the amount of effects it has.           + The Mass Effect series has had a Heavy influence on lots of sci-fi games.Neutral           +- You won't find yourself short on Credits anytime soon. Every mission is funded by Cerberus, and will include at least a 20,000 credit payroll at the end of the mission. You can also find additional credits on PDA's, Terminals, Wall Safe's, and (for some reason), Medi-kits. However, Purchases are evened out to higher prices to even this out.           +- "I'm Commander Shepard, and this is my favourite store on the Citadel." You can endorse numerous stores on the Citadel with this line, which could technically create conflicts. It has no effect on the game though. However, this isn't a good way of laying low if you choose to tell the security guards at the entrance you would prefer the records to state that Shepard has died. Again, endorsing numerous stores has no effect on that choice.           +- It requires a little bit of work to transfer your ME2 save file to ME3, due to ME3 only being available to Origin.Cons           - The game has DLC, but it's not available on Steam.           - If Shepard dies in the end-game, you can not import your save to ME3.           - Mini-games can get repetitive.Final DecisionI highly recommend this game. Mass Effect had a large impact on the Sci-Fi genre, and for good reason. I'll admit I had to cut a few points due to character limit, but I covered most of it. This is a fantastic game series, 8.9/10.

r 26, 2013
												A truly great sequel which is on par, if not better than the first game. Where the first game had the best story(imo), this sequel greatly expanded upon the gameplay elements. Where the first game was clearly a rpg, this sequel has been labeled as an actionrpg, to reach out to a broader audience. Many would say that this is a bad thing, but the game is more fluid as well as some of the rpg elements have been toned down. That isn't necessarily a bad thing as this was often quite grueling in Mass Effect 1. So overall it expands on its predecessor when it comes to gameplay, lore and characters. Even though the story in Mass Effect 1 was better(again imo), this sequel still got an epic storyline as it is a continuation of the first game.

content:
28, 2013
												Let me say before anything else that this really surprised me as much as the first game. The side quests and the anomalies, newly introduced in Mass Effect 2, in the first game the side quests and some of the main quests required you to use your Mako to travel around the landscape and go to the where the action really began. In Mass Effect 2 you don't need even to travel around the planet, I really enjoyed watching the landscape while driving in the first game but after you got inside the buildings where the quests were taking place the level design was always the same and after some missions you would probably get bored, but in this game they totally improved these aspects. Every single quest has an an unique level design and there are so many backgrounds which look ABSOLUTLY GORGEOUS. Doing the side quests was in no way boring but completly a pleasure for me. Now, you certainly remember that in Mass Effect there was little micro-management or perhaps you can say that there was none at all, you had credits, medi-gel and omni-gel, nothing more and you could just get TONS of creds by selling pretty much everything you didnt needed on the stores. In Mass Effect 2 there's alot of stuff added to the "resource management", for example, remember that quest in the first game in which you had to survey several planets for resources for the Alliance? Well now you actually have a mini-game other than just clicking "SURVEY" one that is actually entertaining and requires you to purchase probes at the fuel depots, which of course, cost credits. Those resources that you acquire from mining/surveying can be used to acquire new upgrades for your weapons and/or research new weaponry, this ended up excluding the looting of weapons which was possible on the first game. Other than buying upgrades for yourself and your squad you can actually purchase upgrades for the Normandy which actually will help you in the end game. Each member that you add to your squad grants you with new upgrades for both your squad and your ship. Now the combat, it is pretty much like the first one but in my opinion you don't really feel as much "overpowered" as in the first game because there's no mods for the weapons and the guns have alot more recoil in Mass Effect 2 and you also have limited ammo making the use of your powers a must, making this way, the combat alot better than in the first Mass Effect. The space exploration has alot more depth into it now, with the adding of fuel using while travelling, you can also purchase fuel in fuel depots for credits. The story continues where the first game left of and it is just incredible in my opinion, one of the best I've seen and experienced in a long while with the soundtrack keeping up to par with the cutscenes and the emotinal moments which are capable of making a sensitive person cry. The character design is as good as the story as far as I'm concerned didn't really noticed someone "where it doesn't belong". Every single squad member has their own unique personality and even the geth,  "Legion", and EDI have a very interesting dialogue. There's also the love story in which you decide you want to take part or not. The Codex keeps up the great job in providing you with aditional information and "lore" which you don't find in the characters dialogues. And of course, surprisingly enough the choices you made on the first game carry on to this one and the ones that you make in Mass Effect 2 will carry on to the third game. I honestly don't know what more I can say about it, it's an awesome game and experience that both role playing and shooting fans most definatly will enjoy but I judge this game by it's storyline so the 2 games I've played so far are for me only one and for that I can say it is really a hell of a game that you should try.

content:
y 1, 2012
												Mass Effect 2 is an amazing action-rpg with great third person shooting mechanics.  The combat is very fun but not what makes Mass Effect so unforgettable.  The highlight is the characters, the way you interact with them, and the choices you make.  The characters are fully fleshed out and many of the game's missions are dedicated to gaining your allies' loyalty and learning more about them.  The ways you interact with them and decisions you make in the game, or have made in Mass Effect 1, have consequences both grand and subtle.  They combine to make the game one of the most personalized gaming experiences out there.Many triple A games aim to deliver an epic experience, and I won't claim that they fail.  But Mass Effect 2 is probably the most epic game I am familiar with.  Its epicness cannot be overstated and in fact its epicness is quantitatively thrice as large as the epicness of other triple A games whose epicness is the main selling point.  Yet despite the incredible epicness of Mass Effect 2 (and I am in no way discrediting the power of epicness), it doesn't neglect to add incredible depth to its characters and choices.

												I cant think of another example of how gaming could be done right, better than the Mass Effect series.An epic trilogy that spans three games in which you are in control of how the story evolves around you.Mass Effect 2 lived up to everything that was expected of this great space epic and is an amzing sequel to the its predecessor.Pros:-Ability to import ME 1 character and profile-Very good animation and graphics, voice acting is great-Great Combat with new powers and weapons-Streamlined Upgrades and Weapons-Your choices shape the story (especially the ones from the first game)-Even more characters, with interesting backstories-Side quest are more tied in and diverse-Very engaging story-REPLAYABILITYCons:-Planet Scanning for upgradesBioware did a great job taking Mass Effect to the next level and clearly deserves better than being owned by EA, but the Mass Effect series is sill the best example of how passionate game making is done right.

												I don't understand why would anyone check the user reviews of this game. Dude, this game is one of the best games out there. The Mass Effect trilogy is, in my book, the best one in the entire gaming history. By far. I don't care what anyone have to say about the third game. content:
ber 4, 2013
												While Mass Effect (1) was a good story, had some good elements, the game was simply one of the worst, mechanically speaking, games I've played in a long time, yes I understand I'm late to the party, and that its and old and was an experimental game, but the mechanics itself put me so much off the series when I played it at release, and still do when I now try to play it again, its simply a waste of time and not to my liking. Simply watch a video or read the lore to get the story of it, and jump to Mass Effect 2 right away!Mass Effect 2 is in every single way better. It's smoother, game-play feels a lot better, the game mechanics are pretty damn solid now and the story, is a blast.The game is very good at making you feel in control of the crew, the ship and last but not least, control of your character. You feel bound to the people around you, you feel their pain, happiness and suffering.While you progress the "main" story arc, you will get multiple "side-missions" that will not only give you rewards and experience, but also in some ways, make you feel more connected to the planets and galaxies, giving you a higher incentive of beating anything in your path, anything for humanity and the safety of the galaxy, you clearly show, no matter who's in charge, you will get the job done.And with the help of people you meet along the way, recruit, talk to, consider your closest allies, you can take down even greater threats.Along the story arc line, your companions will ask you for help, doing so will make them more "Loyal" towards you and what you stand for, but it's not all a cakewalk, you get to see some dark sides of certain characters that change the view of them completely, they can put you in hard spots, do you do as they want? Do you keep them from doing something stupid? What is right? And, what is wrong?In the end it's all up to you to decide, and it will reflect on you, and your ship crew.So the question then is, should you play this or not? Is it worth the price? Hellyeah it is, the game can get picked up for cheap and nothing now, Mass Effect 2 is a huge improvement over its predecessor, not only in the way the game looks, but the game mechanics in general are a lot more smooth, feel good to use and best of all, no more irritating screens that pop up and take hours away.

content:
7, 2015
												I feel that comparisions to the original game is necessary when writing a review for Mass Effect 2, so here it goes:1. Like Mass Effect, Mass Effect 2 is a story-rich 3rd-person FPS where you play as Commander Sheperd. However, the story was not as captivating as ME1 and it seemed that I spent more time assembling and gaining the loyalty of my crew than on the main campaign, which in retrospect was pretty short and straightforward.2. The combat system was an improvement from ME1, where it was much easier to utilise abilities (both yours and your squad's) by binding them to the numerical keys. However, combat got really repetitive after a while. The hacking/ bypassing system was also an improvement, although mostly unnecessary and also repetitive. 3. Anyone who played the original game would remember the dreadfully long elevator rides. Thankfully, ME2 had smoother transitioning and also higher quality cut-scenes which were very enjoyable.4. Like in ME1, it was possible to flirt/ develop relationships with a number of crewmates, although you would have to complete your target's loyalty quest before you could express interest. However, I was disappointed when Liara (ME1 character) could not be recruited into my squad, even though she did make an appearance in the game.I gave ME1 a rating of 9.5/10 only because of the elevator rides. While ME2 was a good game, it seemed to be lacking in story and also its descent into repetitiveness. 8.5/10

content:
ry 28, 2014
												I have not finished playing Mass Effect 2, however I applaud it and its predecessor for its creative use of modern physics to penetrate, if only slightly, the vast distances that lie between stars. Mass Effect 2 also adds more realistic flight sequences, as one has to calculate how much fuel will get them to their destination, acknowledging that fuel is, in fact, a finite resource. However, it does to some extent ignore Newton's first law in that one slows to a halt the minute the ship ceases to accelerate, however, there are worse gripes to be had about a video game than "It follows Aristotelian physics," as Aristotle essentially laid the groundwork for all modern thought.One of my favorite things to do as Commander Shepard was to probe undiscovered worlds, as this was something that I did in real life with the Voyager Probes. However, I doubt that these probes contained anything like the Golden Record that we put together, as First Contact has already been established in the Mass Effect universe.

content:
er 20, 2014
												I give this game a recommendation *ONLY* for the diverse sci-fi tapestry that forms the background to a shallow storyline.  It is obvious the time and energy that went into the computer entrie surrounding the alien races, their homeworlds their history and even their prejudices FAR outweighed the time and energy spent on other things. Not to mention the energy spent on making the communities you encounter seem vibrant and alive.  That being said there is ALOT of regurgitation from KOTOR especially the second.  When I first watched the Ebon Hawk... errr I mean the "Normandy" land on Omega my jaw dropped (the whole scene, it seemed to me, was ripped from KOTOR 2).  Till I realized that ME2 was made by Bioware. Still if video game developers were more like writers half of the cutscenes and characters would come with a disclaimer in the corner *Reproduced From An Earlier Work*.  These things mostly lead to loud guffaws from me as I watched something that seemed so unnervingly similar to somthing I had seen before...... felt like I was playing a KOTOR 3 that lost the rights to use the Star Wars I.P. The other thing about Mass Effect is the constant similarity to Star Trek.  The whole thing with Shepard falling onto a planet, project Lazarus (sounding like a nod to Project Genesis from "The Search for Spock") even the Geth being ideologically near identical to the BORG.  Two major negatives are the semi-dependance on ownership of the first Mass Effect to get crew members and certain side quests (nothing major really just unfortunate to me) and the fact that I found this in the RPG genre when really it's not.  Good for a nice sci-fi vacation but don't expect it to break much from the KOTOR mold that it was obviously pressed from.

er 20, 2016
												This is honestly one of the best games I've ever played.  It's main flaws are outside factors, such as hard to access DLC, with major features locked behind paywalls.But overall, the game is solid, focused and tells a story that is easy to get invested in.  You come to know your squadmates well, and the game encourages you to explore your relationships.  And of course, there's plenty of character building and shooty action.  But there's a lot of RP in this RPG, and that's in stark contrast to some newer games that claim that genre.If you like scifi, epic storytelling, romance subplots, third person shooting, or games that let you make meaningful choices, ME2 is a game for you.

content:
y 1, 2012
												Mass Effect 2 is an amazing action-rpg with great third person shooting mechanics.  The combat is very fun but not what makes Mass Effect so unforgettable.  The highlight is the characters, the way you interact with them, and the choices you make.  The characters are fully fleshed out and many of the game's missions are dedicated to gaining your allies' loyalty and learning more about them.  The ways you interact with them and decisions you make in the game, or have made in Mass Effect 1, have consequences both grand and subtle.  They combine to make the game one of the most personalized gaming experiences out there.Many triple A games aim to deliver an epic experience, and I won't claim that they fail.  But Mass Effect 2 is probably the most epic game I am familiar with.  Its epicness cannot be overstated and in fact its epicness is quantitatively thrice as large as the epicness of other triple A games whose epicness is the main selling point.  Yet despite the incredible epicness of Mass Effect 2 (and I am in no way discrediting the power of epicness), it doesn't neglect to add incredible depth to its characters and choices.

content:
er 24, 2016
												I was going back and forth on what game to nominate for the "Test of Time" award. And while I was debating I realized there's only one game (series) that I've played damn near ten or more times by now, and that I STILL plan on playing again in the near future. The world esign, lore, characters, and storytelling just don't get old to me. And the variety you can play with throughout the three games is just immense with the different character classes, backgrounds, gender (holy cow if you only play games as one gender you're missing out), and just that your choices affect the future games beginning in Mass Effect 1. Mass Effect 2 gets the award simply because the updated game design over Mass Effect 1 make it the truly timeless entry in a 3 part franchise that is amazing in all three parts. Mass Effect 2 would still get it over Mass Effect 3 because of its ability to stand on its own however. You get a bunch of new companions as well as a couple old friends, meet up with old ones for just mere cameos with dialogue that can get enough of a backstory across, travel to mostly different locations with some familiar places, and the enemy and ending sequence are fully contained (you meet and defeat the main enemy, the Collectors, within the context of Mass Effect 2). The DLC is great in that all of the story packs add to an already complete game and the Arrival DLC wraps the ending up and sets up the sequel perfectly.
